text: Wembley today was a family day out at
the Raleigh celebration and a political
rally rolled into one
Narendra Modi is a controversial figure
back home but listening to this audience
you wouldn't know it tell me why are you
here today um to show how important it
is to me as a young person in Britain
and to be Indian and what it really
means to Indian and understand a bit
more about our nation about our culture
I want to support Modi he is doing a
good job and I'm very proud of you
he has raised the international image of
India to a height degree an honor to see
someone from your background come here
to the UK and just like embrace the
diversity with the air heavy with
feelgood factor the warm up hats of
British Indian talent went down well but
the biggest roar of the afternoon was
inevitably preserved for Prime Minister
Modi himself his British counterpart
with whom 10 billion pounds worth of
trade deals have been done gamely played
host but it was Narendra Modi who stole
the show this is a historic day
for a great partnership and you are the
heartbeat earlier in the day a more
sedate encounter as mr. Modi had lunch
in Buckingham Palace with the Queen for
a man who in the last decade was banned
from the UK it's quite a turnaround in
fortunes some of the controversy still
sticks to him protests have dogged his
visits critics say he champions only the
rights of Indian Hindus and is
intolerant of minorities that people
like Modi who are basically ignoring the
rights of minorities who are trying to
make us all into one big monoculture
which is basically Hindu nationalism
this is not what we stand for but if mr.
Modi came here to milk the Indian
diaspora he certainly succeeded a rock
star setting for the leader of an
emerging power he could have wished for
nothing more free to chakrabarti BBC
news Wembley
